_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: City of Portland Fire and Rescue

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.1    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Safety at Blount is inherent in the manner in which anhydrous ammonia is handled. While the design of the facility incorporates multiple safety devices, safe handling procedures, maintaining mechanical integrity, and appropriate training of our personnel are key aspects to safety at our facility.



Blount has implemented a process safety management (PSM) program that complies with the regulations stipulated by Oregon Administrative Rules (OAR) ?1910.119, which requires Blount to implement integrated safeguards to prevent an ammonia release. A crucial component of this plan is the emergency action plan, developed in compliance with the emergency planning provisions of OAR Chapter 437 Division 002. The emergency action plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordination with outside parties to enable coordinated action to effectively deal with unplanned events.



1.2    Facility Description and Substances Handled



Blount operates an anhydrous ammonia refrigeration processes to refrigerate food products such as soups, entrees, deserts, and sauces. Production requires the use of a refrigeration system to preserve the integrity of foods, and Blount uses ammonia as the refrigerant. Access to the facility is limited to authorized employees, management personnel, and contractors.



1.3    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Blount's written PSM plan incorporates many policies and procedures to ensure safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration equipment. Plan elements essential to safe operation of the refrigeration system include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis (PHA), operating procedures, training, contractor safety, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, management of change, hot-work permits, incident investigation, emergency response and planning, and compliance audits. This plan will b

e reviewed annually, audited every three years, and updated as necessary by Blount.



Training is provided to ensure that each employee involved in operating the refrigeration system understands the refrigeration process, the operating procedures, and safety considerations. Only qualified maintenance personnel operate the refrigeration system.



1.4    Five-Year Accident History



There have been no reportable accidents at the Blount facility in the past five years. 



1.5    Emergency Planning and Response



Blount has a written emergency action plan to ensure that precautions and procedures are in place to protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical emergency. It complies with the provisions of OAR Chapter 437 Division 002. The emergency action plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties. This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events. This plan has been provided to and reviewed with Portland Fire and Rescue.



The approach in the development of this plan has been to identify the ammonia emergencies most likely to occur at Blount and to establish precautions and procedures to protect life, safety, and health during an emergency. The refrigeration process has backup prevention systems to keep processing malfunctions from becoming ammonia release emergencies. If an emergency does occur, Blount has trained personnel to immediately notify the Portland Fire Department and take defensive actions to mitigate the release. Automatic alarms, shutdown systems, and controls have been designed to minimize the potential for an uncontrolled release.



All Blount personnel are trained to fulfill their designated responsibilities in an emergency. Mock emergency drills are held periodically to maintain familiarity with response actions and identify plan elements requiring improvement.



This plan shall be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.



1.6    Planned

Changes to Improve Safety



Any upgrades or extensive maintenance work performed in the future will be in compliance with codes and standards applicable at that time.



Blount completed a process hazard analysis in July, 2021. Higher priority items, such as developing written procedures for certain tasks, are scheduled for completion by August, 2021. Lower priority items, such as evaluating lighting in certain areas are scheduled for completion by the end of 2022. Blount will track assigned target dates and the completion status of all PHA recommendations to ensure items are addressed promptly.
